verses.original:
ओ-न्नमो भगवते॑ रुद्रा॒य ॥
नम॑स्ते रुद्र म॒न्यव॑ उ॒तोत॒ इष॑वे॒ नमः॑ ।
नम॑स्ते अस्तु॒ धन्व॑ने बा॒हुभ्या॑मु॒त ते॒ नमः॑ ॥ ...
... नमः॑ ॥१॥
श्री शम्भ॑वे॒ नमः॑ ॥
नम॑स्ते अस्तु भगवन्-विश्वेश्व॒राय॑ महादे॒वाय॑ त्र्यम्ब॒काय॑ त्रिपुरान्त॒काय॑
त्रिकाग्निका॒लाय॑ कालाग्निरु॒द्राय॑ नीलक॒ण्ठाय॑
मृत्युञ्ज॒याय॑ सर्वेश्व॒राय॑ सदाशि॒वाय॑ [शङ्क॒राय॑] श्रीम-न्महादे॒वाय॒ नमः॑ ।
verses.transliteration:
ō-nnamō bhagavatē̍ rudrā̠ya ॥
nama̍stē rudra ma̠nyava̍ u̠tōta̠ iṣa̍vē̠ nama̍ḥ ।
nama̍stē astu̠ dhanva̍nē bā̠hubhyā̍mu̠ta tē̠ nama̍ḥ ॥ ...
... nama̍ḥ ॥ 1 ॥
śrī śambha̍vē̠ nama̍ḥ ॥
nama̍stē astu bhagavan-viśvēśva̠rāya̍ mahādē̠vāya̍ tryamba̠kāya̍ tripurānta̠kāya̍ trikāgnikā̠lāya̍ kālāgniru̠drāya̍ nīlaka̠ṇṭhāya̍ mṛtyuñja̠yāya̍ sarvēśva̠rāya̍ sadāśi̠vāya̍ [śaṅka̠rāya̍] śrīma-nmahādē̠vāya̠ nama̍ḥ ।
verses.translation: Oṃ, salutations to the adorable Rudra. Salutation to your wrath, O Rudra, and also to your arrow! Salutation to your bow, and to your two arms! May your arrow, which is most auspicious, and your bow, be auspicious; O Rudra, gracious to us with that auspicious missile of yours! O Girisha (dweller in the mountains), with your auspicious form, which is not fierce and reveals no evil, look upon us with favor. O Girisha (dweller in the mountains), make auspicious the arrow you hold in your hand for shooting; O Girishanta, do not harm our people or the world. We address you, Girisha, with auspicious words, so that all this world may be free from disease and cheerful. May that divine physician, the supreme advocate, speak for us, destroying all serpents and all demons. That copper-red, bright red, and auspiciously reddish-brown one, and the thousands of Rudras around him dwelling in the directions, we deprecate their anger. The one descending, the blue-necked and reddish-brown one, whom the cowherds and water-carriers have seen, and whom all beings see, may He, being seen, grant us happiness. Remove the string from both ends of your bow; and the arrows in your hand, O adorable one, cast them far away. Salutation to the blue-necked one with a thousand eyes, the granter of wishes! And to his hosts, I offer salutations. Unstring your bow, O thousand-eyed one, with a hundred quivers; having shattered the tips of the shafts, be auspicious and cheerful to us. May the bow of the Kapardin (long-haired god) be unstrung, and his quiver shaft-less. May His arrows be powerless, and His quiver resting. O Mīḍhuṣṭama (greatest benefactor), may the missile in your hand, and your bow, keep us safe from harm from all sides, free from disease. Salutation to your weapon that is not bent (unstrung), and ready to shoot, to both your arms, and to your bow. May the missile of your bow turn away from us on all sides; and may the quiver which is yours, keep it far away from us. Salutations to Śambhu. Salutations to you, O Lord, to the Lord of the Universe, to the Great God (Mahādeva), to the three-eyed one (Tryambaka), to the destroyer of the three cities (Tripurāntaka), to the Lord of the three sacrificial fires, to the Rudra who is the fire of Time, to the blue-necked one (Nīlakaṇṭha), to the conqueror of Death (Mṛtyuñjaya), to the Lord of All (Sarveśvara), to the eternally auspicious one (Sadāśiva), to the glorious Great God, salutation.

verses.original:
नमो॒ हिर॑ण्य बाहवे सेना॒न्ये॑ दि॒शा-ञ्च॒ पत॑ये॒ नमो॒
नमो॑ वृ॒क्षेभ्यो॒ हरि॑केशेभ्यः पशू॒ना-म्पत॑ये॒ नमो॒ ...
... नमः॑ कृत्स्नवी॒ताय॒ धाव॑ते॒ सत्त्व॑ना॒-म्पत॑ये॒ नमः॑ ॥२॥
verses.transliteration:
namō̠ hira̍ṇya bāhavē sēnā̠nyē̍ di̠śā-ñcha̠ pata̍yē̠ namō̠
namō̍ vṛ̠kṣēbhyō̠ hari̍kēśēbhyaḥ paśū̠nā-mpata̍yē̠ namō̠ ...
... nama̍ḥ kṛtsnavī̠tāya̠ dhāva̍tē̠ sattva̍nā̠-mpata̍yē̠ nama̍ḥ ॥ 2 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the gold-armed one, the general, and the Lord of the quarters. Salutation to the trees, with green hair (leaves), and the Lord of the cattle. Salutation to the yellowish-brown, brilliant one, and the Lord of the pathways. Salutation to the brown one, the piercer, and the Lord of food. Salutation to the green-haired one, wearing the sacred thread, and the Lord of the nourished. Salutation to Bhava’s missile, and the Lord of the worlds. Salutation to Rudra with the unstrung bow, and the Lord of the fields. Salutation to the charioteer, the unconquerable one, and the Lord of the forests. Salutation to the reddish one, the architect, and the Lord of the trees. Salutation to the counselor, the merchant, and the Lord of the thickets. Salutation to the pervading one, the benefactor, and the Lord of the medicinal herbs. Salutation to the one with the loud cry, who makes people scream, and the Lord of the infantry. Salutation to the completely encircled one, who runs, and the Lord of the brave ones (sattvas).

verses.original:
नम॒-स्सह॑मानाय निव्या॒धिन॑ आव्या॒धिनी॑ना॒-म्पत॑ये नमो॒
नमः॑ ककु॒भाय॑ निष॒ङ्गिणे᳚ स्ते॒नाना॒-म्पत॑ये॒ नमो॒ ...
... नमो॒ अश्वे॒भ्यो-ऽश्व॑पतिभ्यश्च वो॒ नमः॑ ॥३॥
verses.transliteration:
nama̠-ssaha̍mānāya nivyā̠dhina̍ āvyā̠dhinī̍nā̠-mpata̍yē namō̠
nama̍ḥ kaku̠bhāya̍ niṣa̠ṅgiṇē̎ stē̠nānā̠-mpata̍yē̠ namō̠ ...
... namō̠ aśvē̠bhyō-‘śva̍patibhyaścha vō̠ nama̍ḥ ॥ 3 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the enduring one, the close piercer, and the Lord of the female archers. Salutation to the prominent one, carrying a sword, and the Lord of the thieves. Salutation to the one with a sword and a quiver, and the Lord of the robbers. Salutation to the deceiver and the complete deceiver, and the Lord of the lurkers. Salutation to the wanderer and the prowler, and the Lord of the forest dwellers. Salutation to those with lances, who wish to kill, and the Lord of the plunderers. Salutation to those with swords, who roam at night, and the Lord of the cutters. Salutation to the turbaned one, who walks on the mountains, and the Lord of the field-marauders. Salutation to those who have arrows and those who have bows, salutation to you. Salutation to those who string the bow and those who place the arrow, salutation to you. Salutation to those who pull and those who release the arrows, salutation to you. Salutation to those who are sitting (stationary) and those who are striking, salutation to you. Salutation to those who are sitting and those who are lying down, salutation to you. Salutation to those who are sleeping and those who are awake, salutation to you. Salutation to those who are standing and those who are running, salutation to you. Salutation to the assemblies and their chairmen, salutation to you. Salutation to the horses and their masters, salutation to you.

verses.original:
नम॑ आव्या॒धिनी᳚भ्यो वि॒विध्य॑न्तीभ्यश्च वो॒ नमो॒
नम॒ उग॑णाभ्यस्तृग्ं-ह॒तीभ्य॑श्च वो॒ नमो॒ ...
... नम॒-श्श्वभ्य॒-श्श्वप॑तिभ्यश्च वो॒ नमः॑ ॥४॥
verses.transliteration:
nama̍ āvyā̠dhinī̎bhyō vi̠vidhya̍ntībhyaścha vō̠ namō̠
nama̠ uga̍ṇābhyastṛgṃ-ha̠tībhya̍ścha vō̠ namō̠ ...
... nama̠-śśvabhya̠-śśvapa̍tibhyaścha vō̠ nama̍ḥ ॥ 4 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the female archers and those who strike diversely, salutation to you. Salutation to the fierce bands and those who destroy utterly, salutation to you. Salutation to the greedy and the chiefs of the greedy, salutation to you. Salutation to the roving bands and the chiefs of the roving bands, salutation to you. Salutation to the multitudes and the leaders of the multitudes, salutation to you. Salutation to the deformed and those with manifold forms, salutation to you. Salutation to the great and the small, salutation to you. Salutation to the charioteers and those without chariots, salutation to you. Salutation to the chariots and the masters of the chariots, salutation to you. Salutation to the armies and the leaders of the armies, salutation to you. Salutation to the charioteers and the collectors (of tribute), salutation to you. Salutation to the carpenters and the chariot-makers, salutation to you. Salutation to the potters and the blacksmiths, salutation to you. Salutation to the fowlers and the hunters (Niṣādas), salutation to you. Salutation to the arrow-makers and the bow-makers, salutation to you. Salutation to the hunters and the dog-keepers, salutation to you. Salutation to the dogs and the masters of the dogs, salutation to you.

verses.original:
नमो॑ भ॒वाय॑ च रु॒द्राय॑ च॒
नमः॑ श॒र्वाय॑ च पशु॒पत॑ये च॒ ...
... नमः॑ स्रोत॒स्या॑य च॒ द्वीप्या॑य च ॥५॥
verses.transliteration:
namō̍ bha̠vāya̍ cha ru̠drāya̍ cha̠
nama̍-śśa̠rvāya̍ cha paśu̠pata̍yē cha̠ ...
... nama̍-ssrōta̠syā̍ya cha̠ dvīpyā̍ya cha ॥ 5 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to Bhava and to Rudra. Salutation to Śarva and to the Lord of the cattle. Salutation to the blue-necked one and to the one with the white throat. Salutation to the Kapardin (matted hair) and to the one with shorn hair. Salutation to the thousand-eyed one and to the one with a hundred bows. Salutation to the dweller on the mountain and to the one who is clothed in rays (Śipiviṣṭa). Salutation to the greatest benefactor and to the one holding the arrow. Salutation to the short one and to the dwarf. Salutation to the great one and to the oldest. Salutation to the old one and to the one who causes growth. Salutation to the foremost and to the first. Salutation to the swift one and to the quick one. Salutation to the quickly moving one and to the rapid one. Salutation to the one dwelling in the waves and to the one dwelling in the still waters. Salutation to the one dwelling in the streams and to the one dwelling in the islands.

verses.original:
नमो᳚ ज्ये॒ष्ठाय॑ च कनि॒ष्ठाय॑ च॒
नमः॑ पूर्व॒जाय॑ चापर॒जाय॑ च॒ ...
... नमः॑ श्रु॒ताय॑ च श्रुतसे॒नाय॑ च॥ ६॥
verses.transliteration:
namō̎ jyē̠ṣṭhāya̍ cha kani̠ṣṭhāya̍ cha̠
nama̍ḥ pūrva̠jāya̍ chāpara̠jāya̍ cha̠ ...
... nama̍-śśru̠tāya̍ cha śrutasē̠nāya̍ cha ॥ 6 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the eldest and to the youngest. Salutation to the one born before and to the one born after. Salutation to the middle one and to the undeveloped one. Salutation to the lowest and to the fundamental one. Salutation to the one in the tank and to the one in the flowing water. Salutation to the one on the right (Yāmya) and to the one in the field (Kṣemya). Salutation to the one in the fertile land and to the one on the threshing floor. Salutation to the one in hymns and to the one at the conclusion of rites. Salutation to the one in the forest and to the one in the thicket. Salutation to the sound and to the echo. Salutation to the one with the swift army and to the one with the swift chariot. Salutation to the hero and to the destroyer. Salutation to the one wearing armor and to the one with a protective cover (Varūdhin). Salutation to the one with a helmet and to the one with a coat of mail (Kavachin). Salutation to the one who is heard of (famous) and to the one with a famous army.

verses.original:
नमो॑ दुन्दु॒भ्या॑य चाहन॒न्या॑य च॒
नमो॑ धृ॒ष्णवे॑ च प्रमृ॒शाय॑ च॒ ...
... नमो॑ वास्त॒व्या॑य च वास्तु॒पाय॑ च ॥ ७॥
verses.transliteration:
namō̍ dundu̠bhyā̍ya chāhana̠nyā̍ya cha̠
namō̍ dhṛ̠ṣṇavē̍ cha pramṛ̠śāya̍ cha̠ ...
... namō̍ vāsta̠vyā̍ya cha vāstu̠pāya̍ cha ॥ 7 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the one in the war-drum and to the one on the drum-stick. Salutation to the bold one and to the spy. Salutation to the messenger and to the sent one. Salutation to the one with the quiver and to the one with the arrow-case. Salutation to the one with sharp arrows and to the one with a weapon. Salutation to the one with a good weapon and to the one with a good bow. Salutation to the one in the path and to the one on the high road. Salutation to the one in the thorny thicket and to the one in the marshes. Salutation to the one in the pools and to the one in the lakes. Salutation to the one in the rivers and to the one on the forest pools (Vaiśanta). Salutation to the one in the wells and to the one in the pits. Salutation to the one in the rain and to the one in the drought. Salutation to the one in the clouds and to the one in the lightning. Salutation to the one in the hailstorm and to the one in the sunshine. Salutation to the one in the wind and to the one in the whirlwind. Salutation to the one in the dwelling and to the Lord of the dwelling.

verses.original:
नम॒-स्सोमा॑य च रु॒द्राय॑ च॒
नम॑स्ता॒म्राय॑ चारु॒णाय॑ च॒ ...
... नमः॑ सिक॒त्या॑य च प्रवा॒ह्या॑य च ॥ ८॥
verses.transliteration:
nama̠-ssōmā̍ya cha ru̠drāya̍ cha̠
nama̍stā̠mrāya̍ chāru̠ṇāya̍ cha̠ ...
... nama̍-ssika̠tyā̍ya cha pravā̠hyā̍ya cha ॥ 8 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to Soma and to Rudra. Salutation to the copper-red and to the dawn-red. Salutation to Śaṅkha (the bestower of happiness) and to the Lord of the cattle. Salutation to the terrible and to the frightful. Salutation to the one who kills from nearby and to the one who kills from afar. Salutation to the slayer and to the most deadly. Salutation to the trees with green hair (leaves). Salutation to the star (Tāra). Salutation to the source of happiness and to the cause of joy. Salutation to the one who brings happiness and to the one who produces comfort. Salutation to the auspicious one and to the most auspicious one. Salutation to the one on the ford and to the one on the river bank. Salutation to the one on the far bank and to the one on the near bank. Salutation to the one who makes others cross over and to the one who helps others cross over. Salutation to the one who comes to the bank and to the one who plays near the water. Salutation to the one on the fresh grass and to the one in the foam. Salutation to the one in the sand and to the one in the swiftly flowing water.

verses.original:
नम॑ इरि॒ण्या॑य च प्रप॒थ्या॑य च॒
नमः॑ किग्ंशि॒लाय॑ च॒ क्षय॑णाय च॒ ...
... नम॑ आमीव॒त्केभ्यः॑ ॥ ९॥
verses.transliteration:
nama̍ iri̠ṇyā̍ya cha prapa̠thyā̍ya cha̠
nama̍ḥ kigṃśi̠lāya̍ cha̠ kṣaya̍ṇāya cha̠ ...
... nama̍ āmīva̠tkēbhya̍ḥ ॥ 9 ॥
verses.translation: Salutation to the one in the barren land and to the one on the highway. Salutation to the one with small pebbles and to the one who destroys. Salutation to the Kapardin (matted hair) and to the one who destroys demons (Pulastin). Salutation to the one in the cow-shed and to the one in the house. Salutation to the one on the bed and to the one in the house. Salutation to the one in the thorny thicket and to the one dwelling in the deep ravines. Salutation to the one in the lakes and to the one dwelling in the swampy ground. Salutation to the one in the dust and to the one in the mist. Salutation to the one in the dry spot and to the one in the green spot. Salutation to the one in the desolate place and to the one in the weedy place. Salutation to the one on the ground and to the one in the soft mud. Salutation to the one on the leaves and to the one on the leaf-litter. Salutation to the one who raises his hand (threateningly) and to the one who smites. Salutation to the one who causes pain and to the one who causes great pain. Salutation to you, the dispersers (Kirikas), who are the hearts of the Gods. Salutation to the diminished ones, salutation to the discriminators. Salutation to the completely destroyed ones, salutation to the afflicted ones.

verses.original:
द्रापे॒ अन्ध॑सस्पते॒ दरि॑द्र॒न्नील॑लोहित ।
ए॒षा-म्पुरु॑षाणामे॒षा-म्प॑शू॒ना-म्मा भेर्मा-ऽरो॒ मो ए॑षा॒-ङ्किञ्च॒नाम॑मत् । ...
... तासा॒मीशा॑नो भगवः परा॒चीना॒ मुखा॑ कृधि ॥ १०॥
verses.transliteration:
drāpē̠ andha̍saspatē̠ dari̍dra̠nnīla̍lōhita ।
ē̠ṣā-mpuru̍ṣāṇāmē̠ṣā-mpa̍śū̠nā-mmā bhērmā-‘rō̠ mō ē̍ṣā̠-ṅkiñcha̠nāma̍mat । ...
... tāsā̠mīśā̍nō bhagavaḥ parā̠chīnā̠ mukhā̍ kṛdhi ॥ 10 ॥
verses.translation: O Drape (One who drives away), Lord of food, O poor one (in form) and blue-red one (Nīlalohita)! Do not frighten these men and these cattle, nor cause disease, nor cause any one of them to suffer. May your most auspicious form, O Rudra, that is full of universal healing medicine and is the medicine of Rudra, grant us happiness to live. We offer our devotion to this strong, matted-haired Rudra, the destroyer of foes, so that there may be welfare for bipeds and quadrupeds, and so that all things in this village may be well-nourished and free from sickness. O Rudra, grant us happiness and create comfort for us. With salutation, we worship you, the destroyer of foes. May we obtain the bliss and peace which Manu, our father, attained through sacrifice, when led by you, O Rudra. Do not kill our great ones or our young ones, do not kill our growing ones or our born ones, do not kill our father or our mother, do not injure our dear bodies, O Rudra. Do not injure our children, our grandsons, our life-span, our cattle, or our horses. O Rudra, being angry, do not kill our heroes; we worship you with oblations and salutations. May your missile, which kills cattle and men, O destroyer of foes, be far from us; may your grace be here for us. Protect us, speak well of us, O God, and grant us a two-fold shelter (in this world and the next). Praise the famous one, seated on the chariot (or mount), the young one, the terrible lion-like beast, the fierce one, the destroyer. O Rudra, being praised, be gracious to the worshipper; may your armies strike down others, far from us. May the missile of Rudra turn away from us, and the fierce evil intent of the evil-doer. Unstring your firm bow for the sacrificers, O granter of wishes (Mīḍhvas), and be gracious to our children and grandchildren. O Mīḍhuṣṭama (greatest granter of wishes), O Śivatama (most auspicious), be auspicious and cheerful to us. Place your weapon on a high tree, and come here wearing a skin, holding the Pināka (bow). O Vikirida (scatterer of rewards), O Vilohita (red-hued), salutation to you, O Lord. May those thousands of missiles of yours turn away from us towards someone else. O Lord, your arms hold thousands and thousands of missiles; turn their faces away from us.

verses.original:
स॒हस्रा॑णि सहस्र॒शो ये रु॒द्रा अधि॒ भूम्या᳚म् ।
तेषाग्ं॑ सहस्रयोज॒ने-ऽव॒धन्वा॑नि तन्मसि । ...
... तं-वोँ॒ जम्भे॑ दधामि॥ ११॥
verses.transliteration:
sa̠hasrā̍ṇi sahasra̠śō yē ru̠drā adhi̠ bhūmyā̎m ।
tēṣāg̍ṃ sahasrayōja̠nē-‘va̠dhanvā̍ni tanmasi । ...
... taṃ vō̠ jambhē̍ dadhāmi ॥ 11 ॥
verses.translation: The thousands upon thousands of Rudras who are on the earth, we unstring their bows a thousand leagues away. The Bhavas (Rudras) who are in this great ocean, in the atmosphere, the blue-necked, white-throated Śarvas (Rudras) who wander on the earth below. The blue-necked, white-throated Rudras who abide in the sky. The Rudras who are yellowish-brown, blue-necked, and reddish-brown in the trees. The Rudras who are the Lords of the Bhūtas (beings), with tufted hair, matted locks. The Rudras who strike people drinking from vessels in their food. The Rudras who are the protectors of the paths, who are the givers of food and the protectors of grain. The Rudras who move at the fords, carrying spears and swords. The Rudras who are so many and still more, who are established in the quarters. Their bows, we unstring them a thousand leagues away. Salutation to the Rudras who are on the earth, in the atmosphere, and in the sky, whose arrows are food, wind, and rain, to them, ten East, ten South, ten West, ten North, and ten above, to them salutation. May they be gracious to us. He whom we hate and who hates us, him we consign to your jaws.

verses.original:
त्र्य॑म्बकं-यँजामहे सुग॒न्धि-म्पु॑ष्टि॒वर्ध॑नम् ।
उ॒र्वा॒रु॒कमि॑व॒ बन्ध॑नान्मृत्यो॑र्मुक्षीय॒ मा-ऽमृता᳚त् । ...
... ॐ शान्ति॒-श्शान्ति॒-श्शान्तिः॑ ।
verses.transliteration:
trya̍mbakaṃ yajāmahē suga̠ndhi-mpu̍ṣṭi̠vardha̍nam ।
u̠rvā̠ru̠kami̍va̠ bandha̍nānmṛtyō̍rmukṣīya̠ mā-‘mṛtā̎t । ...
... ōṃ śānti̠-śśānti̠-śśānti̍ḥ ।
verses.translation: We worship the three-eyed one (Tryambaka), fragrant, and increasing prosperity. May I be liberated from death, like a cucumber from its stalk, but not from immortality. The Rudra who is in the fire, who is in the waters, who is in the herbs, the Rudra who has entered all worlds, salutation to that Rudra. Praise Him who has good arrows and a good bow, who governs the whole of medicine. We worship Rudra for goodwill; serve the God, the Asura, with salutations. This hand of mine is fortunate, this hand is more fortunate. This hand is the universal healer, this is the gentle touch. The thousands and ten thousands of nooses of Death, meant to destroy mortals—all those, we remove with the power of the sacrifice. Svāhā to Death, Svāhā to Death. Oṃ, salutations to the adorable Rudra-Viṣṇu, protect me from Death. You are the knot of the breaths (Prāṇa), Rudra, do not enter me as the ender (Antaka). Through that food, be nourished. Salutations to Rudra-Viṣṇu, protect me from Death. Sadāśivom. Oṃ Peace, Peace, Peace.

verses.translation: May Agni and Indra be granted to me, Soma and Indra, Savitr and Indra, Sarasvati and Indra, Pūṣan and Indra, Bṛhaspati and Indra, Mitra and Indra, Varuṇa and Indra, Tvaṣṭr and Indra, Dhātṛ and Indra, Viṣṇu and Indra, the Aśvins and Indra, the Maruts and Indra, the Viśve Devas and Indra, Earth and Indra, Atmosphere and Indra, Sky and Indra, directions and Indra, the highest point (Mūrdhā) and Indra, Prajāpati and Indra.

verses.translation: May the Aṁśu (Soma vessel) and the Raśmi (Soma ray) be granted to me, the Adābhya (vessel) and the Adhipati (vessel). May the Upāṁśu (libation) and the Antaryāma (libation) be granted to me. May the Aindravāyava (Graha) and the Maitrāvaruṇa (Graha) be granted to me. May the Āśvina (Graha) and the Pratiprasthāna (Graha) be granted to me. May the Śukra (Graha) and the Manthin (Graha) be granted to me. May the Āgrayaṇa (Graha) and the Vaiśvadeva (Graha) be granted to me. May the Dhruva (Graha) and the Vaiśvānara (Graha) be granted to me. May the Ṛtugrahas (seasonal libations) and the Atigrāhyas (extra libations) be granted to me. May the Aindrāgna (Graha) and the Vaiśvadeva (Graha) be granted to me. May the Marutvatīyas (Graha) and the Māhendra (Graha) be granted to me. May the Āditya (Graha) and the Sāvitra (Graha) be granted to me. May the Sārasvata (Graha) and the Pauṣṇa (Graha) be granted to me. May the Pātnīvata (Graha) and the Hāriyojana (Graha) be granted to me. (All these are names of Soma cups/libations used in the Soma sacrifice.)

May Earth be granted to me, and Aditi (boundless freedom) and Diti (limitation), Sky, the Śakvarī fingers (the digits of the hand), and the directions. May the Ṛk verses be prepared (by the sacrifice), and the Sāma (melodies), the Stoma (hymns of praise), the Yajus (prose formulas), the Dīkṣā (consecration), penance (Tapas), the season (Ṛtu), the sacred vow (Vrata). May the Bṛhat and Rathantara Sāmans (famous Sāman melodies) through the rain of day and night be prepared by the sacrifice.

verses.translation: Oṃ! May Iḍā (the Earth/Food), the invoker of the gods, Manu, the leader of the sacrifice, and Bṛhaspati, the speaker of songs (uktha) of intoxication, and the Viśve Devas, the speakers of good hymns—may they bless me. O Mother Earth, do not injure me. I shall think sweetly, I shall generate sweetness, I shall speak sweetness, I shall utter sweetness, I shall utter for the gods a speech full of honey, and for men, speech that is worthy of being heard. May the gods protect me for the sake of splendor. May the ancestors approve of me. Oṃ! Peace, Peace, Peace.
